location.physicalLocation: British Library: India Office Records and Private Papers

titleInfo.title: Letter No. 393: Lieutenant-Colonel Samuel Hennell, Resident in the Persian Gulf, Bushire, to Commodore John Patterson Porter, Commander of the Indian Naval Squadron in the Persian Gulf

mods.abstract: Samuel Hennell refers to a letter from Lieutenant James Tronson to John Patterson Porter, in which Tronson stated that the only instructions he had received were to act in case of a disturbance with Amulgavine [Umm al-Qaywayn]. Hennell states that the principal object for which a squadron is maintained in these seas is the suppression of piracy and maritime disorder. In the margin he provides a list of members of the maritime truce and states that no hostilities of any kind are to be permitted between their vessels. The members of the truce are listed as follows: Sheik Sultan ben Suggur [Sulṭān bin Saqr Āl Qāsimī] of Ruselkhyma [Ra's-al-Khaymah]; Sheik Abdoollah ben Rashid [Sheikh Abdullah I bin Rashid Al Mu`alla] of Amulgavine [Umm al-Qaywayn]; Sheik Abdool Azeez ben Rashid [Sheikh `Abd al–`Aziz I ibn Rashid Al Nuaimi] of Ejmaun [Ajman]; Sheik Muckhtoom ben Bulye [Sheikh Maktoum bin Butti bin Sohal] of Debaye [Dubai]; and Sheik Saeed ben Tahnoon [Sheikh Said bin Tahnun Al Nahayan] of Aboothabee [Abu Dhabi].
